citeinfo.title: The StreamCat Dataset: Accumulated Attributes for NHDPlusV2 (Version 2.1) Catchments for the Conterminous United States: Surficial Lithology in Watershed

pubinfo.publish: US EPA Office of Research & Development (ORD) - National Health and Environmental Effects Research Laboratory (NHEERL)

descript.abstract:
This dataset represents the density of 18 USGS lithology classes within individual, local NHDPlusV2 catchments and upstream, contributing watersheds(see Data Sources for links to NHDPlusV2 data and USGS). Attributes were calculated for every local NHDPlusV2 catchment and then accumulated to provide watershed-level metrics for USGS lithology data.
This data set is derived from the USGS raster map of 18 lithology classes (categorical data type) for the conterminous USA. The map was produced based on texture, internal structure, thickness, and environment of deposition or formation of materials.
These 18 lithology classes were summarized by local catchment and by watershed to produce 18 local catchment-level and watershed-level metrics as a categorical data type (see Data Structure and Attribute Information for a description of each metric).
descript.purpose: These data were created in support of the US EPA’s National Aquatic Resource Survey (NARS) and Safe and Sustainable Waters Resources (SSWR) Programs. However, these watershed summaries of landscape data should have broad applicability for hydrological, geomorphic, or ecological modeling, management, and restoration. For details on EPA NARS and SSWR Programs see http://water.epa.gov/type/watersheds/monitoring/aquaticsurvey_index.cfm and http://www.epa.gov/research/progressreport/water.htm
descript.supplinf:
All code and scripts used to produce these data were written in the python or R programming languages and are freely available at ftp://newftp.epa.gov/EPADataCommons/ORD/NHDPlusLandscapeAttributes/StreamCat/Documentation/Code/
Glossary of Terms
Stream Segment: NHDPlusV2 line describing a section of contiguous stream or river between upstream and downstream tributaries (as depicted in USGS topographic quadrangles), except where the segment is a headwater or terminal stream .
Catchment (Cat): The portion of the landscape where surface flow drains directly to an NHDPlusV2 stream segment, excluding any upstream contributions.
Watershed (Ws): The set of hydrologically-connected catchments, consisting of all upstream catchments that contribute flow to any local catchment.
COMID: Unique identifier for each stream segment, and associated catchment, in NHDPlusV2. Watershed metrics describe entire area of all catchments that accumulate to the specific catchment based on the NHD PlusFlow table.
Riparian Buffer (Rp100): Spatial buffer of 100-m that was added to NHDPlusV2 stream network and NLCD water pixels. The buffers were used to spatially constrain calculations for some landscape metrics to within 100 meters of the riparian area.
Landscape Layer: Any geospatial layer from which we derived statistical summaries for both local catchments and watersheds. These landscape layers were comprised of several GIS formats, including vector (points, lines, or polygons) and raster.

idinfo.useconst: None. While EPA has used its best efforts to include complete and accurate information in the EME, EPA cannot be held responsible for errors or omissions and is not liable for any direct, indirect or consequential damages resulting from using this information. Reliance on the information contained in this system by any party cannot be used as a defense in any administrative or judicial proceeding. In such proceedings, the specific language of the relevant regulation or statute is binding. Acknowledgement of the EPA would be appreciated.

procstep.procdesc: Dataset downloaded from http://rmgsc.cr.usgs.gov/ecosystems/usa.shtml Data source, date, units and resolution were recorded in a project tracking spreadsheet and verified. Raster was converted to .tif file to match conventions used in this project.
Projection of dataset verified as USGS Albers Equal Area Conic and projected if necessary

Performed a visual inspection of dataset for gaps, edges other anomalous features. Verified how no-data values were represented and recoded values as no-data where appropriate (for instance, if no-data locations represented by 0's or -9999, these were converted to no-data values).

Ran zonal statistics python script (StreamCat.py) to calculate zonal statistics for all NHDPlusV2 catchments in each NHDPlusV2 Vector Processing Unit (VPU). Zonal statistics were perofrmed using either ZonalStatisticsAsTable, TabulateArea, or spatially joining vector point data to catchments. Each method applies to the type of landscape layer being evaluated, Continuous, Categorical, or Point. We also calculated the percent of each catchment that had coverage by a given landscape layer (i.e. was not null). These results are accumulated using the NHDPlusV2 flow table to summarize upstream catchment values and complete watershed values for the metric.

Clean and standardize results of zonal statistics table from accumulation script / process (makeFinalTables.py). Clean up consisted of calculating mean value of metric per zone, renaming and sorting zonal statistics fields, and writing zonal results to .csv file.

citeinfo.origin: United States Geological Survey (USGS) and US EPA
citeinfo.title: National Hydrography Dataset Plus

enttyp.enttypd: Local catchment and accumulated watershed level summary of the percentages of the 18 surficial lithology material classes for the conterminous USA.

attr.attrdef: Unique ID label to each catchment in NHDPlusV2
Area of the catchment measured in square kilometers.
% of the catchment that is covered by the landscape layer.
Area of the local catchment and accumulated upstream catchments composing the entire watershed (Ws) measured in square kilometers.
% of the watershed that is covered by the landscape layer.
% of the catchment classified as lithology type: carbonate residual material. (Class Code: 1)
% of the catchment classified as lithology type: non-carbonate residual material. (Class Code: 3)
% of the catchment classified as lithology type: alkaline intrusive volcanic rock. (Class Code: 4)
% of the catchment classified as lithology type: silicic residual material. (Class Code: 5)
% of the catchment classified as lithology type: extrusive volcanic rock. (Class Code: 7)
% of the catchment classified as lithology type: colluvial sediment. (Class Code: 8)
% of the catchment classified as lithology type: glacial till, clayey. (Class Code: 9)
% of the catchment classified as lithology type: glacial till, loamy. (Class Code:10)
% of the catchment classified as lithology type: glacial till, coarse-textured. (Class Code: 11)
% of the catchment classified as lithology type: glacial outwash and glacial lake sediment, coarse-textured. (Class Code: 12 and 14)
% of the catchment classified as lithology type: glacial lake sediment, fine-textured. (Class Code:13)
% of the catchment classified as lithology type: hydric, peat and muck. (Class Code:15)
% of the catchment classified as lithology type: eolian sediment, coarse-textured (sand dunes). (Class Code:16)
% of the catchment classified as lithology type: eolian sediment, fine-textured (glacial loess). (Class Code: 17)
% of the catchment classified as lithology type: saline like sediment. (Class Code: 18)
% of the catchment classified as lithology type: alluvium and fine-textured coastal zone sediment. (Class Code: 19)
% of the catchment classified as lithology type: coastal zone sediment, coarse-textured. (Class Code: 20)
% of the catchment classified as lithology type: water. (Class Code: 22)
